description: {"blocks":[{"key":"2l39e","text":"Described here is the workflow used by the Female Reproductive Tissue Mapping Center at UCSD to generate extracellular matrix proteomics (ECM) data from human placenta.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
document: {"blocks":[{"key":"9dhrv","text":"Extracellular Matrix (ECM) proteomics for the UCSD Female Reproductive TMC ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":75}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhq4r","text":"Summary of Procedures","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7rpd0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ev48k","text":"Prepare tissue according to the following protocol:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"feel6","text":"Human Placenta Tissue Collection and Preservation Methods - UCSD Female Reproductive TMC","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":88}],"data":{}},{"key":"4005i","text":"For this protocol, use tissue that has been snap-frozen.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3tikg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1k9jj","text":"I. Sample Extraction and Digestion:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14pb1","text":"Lyophilized samples were weighed (~5mgs), and brought up in 50mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), .25% CHAPS, 25mM EDTA, 3M NaCl supplemented with 10ul/mL Halt Protease Arrest. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7phi","text":"Approximately 100 mg of 3mm glass beads were used to mechanically agitate samples in a Bullet Blender","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t2ht","text":"Vortexed @ 4°C for 20 min","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aegs8","text":"Centrifuged at 18,000 x g for 20 minutes, supernatant removed","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6duu","text":"Steps b-d repeated x 2","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dohq5","text":"Pellets subjected to chemical digestion with 1M hydroxylamine hydrochloride (HA) in 6M Gnd-HCl","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65t78","text":"Protein concentration of each sample determined by BCA","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e8co0","text":"Proteolytic digestion was carried out according to the FASP protocol1 with 10 kDa molecular weight cutoff filters (Sartorius Vivacon 500 #VN01H02) using 30 ug of protein resulting from each sample.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":68,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"el220","text":"Samples reduced with tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine), alkylated with 2-chloroacetamide, and digested with trypsin (1:100) at 37ºC for 14 Hrs. Peptides were recovered from the filter using successive washes with 0.2% formic acid. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6oeuk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"engu2","text":"II.LC-MS/MS:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"49aqt","text":"Resulting peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS using a Fusion Lumos Tribrid mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) coupled to an EASY-nLC 1200 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) operating in data dependent acquisition mode. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cf5s0","text":"Raw spectra were interpreted against the human proteome database using the MSFragger-based FragPipe computational platform2","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":122,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"df36i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lkd6","text":"Methods","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7r4t5","text":"Sample preparation for LC-MS/MS","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhmgt","text":"Lyophilized samples were weighed (~5mgs) and brought up in 50mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), .25% CHAPS, 25mM EDTA, 3M NaCl supplemented with 10ul/mL Halt Protease Arrest. Approximately 100 mg of 3mm glass beads were used to mechanically agitate samples in a Bullet Blender (NextAdvance) prior to all cellular and ECM extraction steps. Protein concentration of each fraction for each sample was measured using A660 Protein Assay (Pierce™). Proteolytic digestion was carried out according to the FASP protocol1 with 10 kDa molecular weight cutoff filters (Sartorius Vivacon 500 #VN01H02) using 30 ug of protein resulting from each fraction. Samples reduced with tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine), alkylated with 2-chloroacetamide, and digested with trypsin (1:100) at 37ºC for 14 hrs. Peptides were recovered from the filter using successive washes with 0.2% formic acid. Peptides were recovered from the filter using successive washes with 0.2% formic acid. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":498,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvnkg","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ahdm","text":"LC-MS/MS analysis","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehjgi","text":"Global proteomics for all comparative method testing was carried out on a Fusion Lumos Tribrid mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) coupled to an EASY-nLC 1200 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) through a nanoelectrospray LC − MS interface. Eight μL of each sample was injected into a 20 μL loop using the autosampler. The analytical column was then switched on-line at 400 nl/min over an in house-made 100 μm i.d. × 150 mm fused silica capillary packed with 2.7 μm CORTECS C18 resin (Waters; Milford, MA). LC mobile phase solvents consisted of 0.1% formic acid in water (Buffer A) and 0.1% formic acid in 80% acetonitrile (Buffer B, Optima™ LC/MS, Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh, PA). After 22 uL of sample loading at a maximum column pressure of 700 bar, each sample was separated on a 120-min gradient at a constant flow rate of 400 nL/min. The separation gradient for cell fractions consisted of 6% buffer B from 0 to 3 minutes, followed by a linear gradient from 6 to 42% buffer B from 3 minutes to 105 minutes. Linear gradients from 6 to 36% and 6 to 24% buffer B were utilized from 3 to 105 minutes for the sECM and iECM fractions, respectively. Gradient elution was followed by a linear increase to 55% buffer B from 105 to 110 minutes and further to 95% buffer B from 110 to 111 minutes. Flow at 95% buffer B was maintained from 111 minutes to 120 minutes to remove remaining peptides. Data acquisition was performed using the instrument supplied Xcalibur™ (version 4.5) software. The mass spectrometer was operated in the positive ion mode. Each survey scan of m/z 375–1600 was followed by higher energy collisional dissociation (HCD) MS/MS (30% collision energy) using the standard AGC target and a 35 ms maximum injection time with an isolation width of 1.6 m/z. The orbitrap was used for MS1 and MS2 detection at resolutions of 120,000 and 50,000, respectively. Dynamic exclusion was performed after fragmenting a precursor 1 time for a duration of 45 sec. Singly charged ions were excluded from HCD selection. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8p5om","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mgd3","text":"Data processing","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cart7","text":"Fragmentation spectra were searched against the UniProt humanproteome database using the MSFragger-based FragPipe computational platform2. Contaminants and reverse decoys and were added to the database automatically. The precursor-ion mass tolerance and fragment-ion mass tolerance were set to 10 ppm and .2 Da, respectively. Precursor tolerance was set to ±10 ppm and fragment tolerance was set to ±0.04 Da, allowing for 2 missed cleavages. Fixed modifications were set as carbamidomethyl (C). Variable modifications were set as oxidation (M), oxidation (P) (hydroxyproline), Gln-\u003epyro-Glu (N-term Q), deamidated (NQ), and acetyl (Protein N-term). Results were filtered to 1% FDR at the peptide and protein level. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":136,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":215,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3l8mc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aga8i","text":"1Wiśniewski, J.R., 2016. Quantitative evaluation of filter aided sample preparation (FASP) and multienzyme digestion FASP protocols. Analytical chemistry, 88(10), pp.5438-5443.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":0,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":134,"length":20},{"style":"italic","offset":156,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2dcm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dsqp9","text":"2Kong, A.T., Leprevost, F.V., Avtonomov, D.M., Mellacheruvu, D. and Nesvizhskii, A.I., 2017. MSFragger: ultrafast and comprehensive peptide identification in mass spectrometry–based proteomics. Nature methods, 14(5), pp.513-520.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":0,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":194,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":210,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1cep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"6B3C26B2D0BC11ECAFF60A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.b5j9q4r6"}}}}
